root.para:
This chapter provides background information and examples of controls that may exist in an entity that deals in a high volume of financial instrument transactions, whether for trading or investing purposes. The examples are not meant to be exhaustive, and entities may establish different control environments and processes depending on their size, the industry in which they operate, and the extent of their financial instrument transactions. The following four Technical Questions and Answers (Q&A) sections address internal control:

entry.para: , “Obtaining an Understanding of Business Processes Relevant to Financial Reporting and Communication” 8200.17
This Q&A section addresses whether auditors are required to obtain an understanding of business processes relevant to financial reporting and communication in every audit engagement.
, “Obtaining an Understanding of Internal Control Relevant to the Audit” 8200.18
This Q&A section addresses whether an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit should encompass more than control activities.
, “Obtaining an Understanding of the Controls Relevant to the Audit” 8200.19

This Q&A section addresses whether an understanding of controls relevant to the audit requires that the auditor evaluate the design of controls relevant to the audit and determine whether they have been implemented every year.
, “Control Activities That Are Always Relevant to the Audit” 8200.20
This Q&A section addresses the control activities that are always considered to be relevant in every audit.
, “Control Activities That May Be Relevant to the Audit” 8200.21
This Q&A section addresses the control activities that may vary from audit engagement to audit engagement and may be relevant to the audit (based on the auditor’s judgment).
